content.title: Extremity Vascular Injury
content.summary: Traumatic injury to the peripheral arteries and veins of the upper and lower extremities, requiring prompt recognition and intervention to prevent limb loss.

definitions.definition: Findings mandating immediate exploration: pulsatile bleeding, expanding hematoma, absent distal pulses, palpable thrill, audible bruit, limb ischemia (6 Ps).
Findings requiring further evaluation: history of arterial bleeding, diminished pulse, proximity to major vessel, peripheral nerve deficit, non-expanding hematoma.
Combined bone, soft tissue, vascular, and nerve injury requiring multidisciplinary decision regarding reconstruction versus primary amputation.

key_concepts.explanation: ABI <0.9 suggests arterial injury requiring imaging. Sensitivity >95% for significant injury. Quick, non-invasive screening tool. Normal ABI does not exclude non-occlusive injury (intimal flap).
Hard signs: immediate OR, on-table angiography if needed. Soft signs: CTA has replaced conventional angiography. Proximity alone (without signs): observation or serial exams is acceptable.

Orthopedic stabilization before vascular repair (prevents tension/kinking). Exception: in limb-threatening ischemia, temporary shunt before orthopedic fixation. Fasciotomy should be performed prophylactically with prolonged ischemia.

Primary repair: small lacerations. Patch angioplasty: partial injuries. Interposition graft: segmental injury (autogenous vein preferred). Bypass: when vessels not reconstructible. Ligation: venous injury acceptable, some arterial.

evidence.citation: Frykberg et al., Soft Signs Study, 1991
evidence.finding: Selective management based on physical examination has 99% accuracy for identifying significant injuries

evidence.citation: MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score), Johansen et al., 1990
evidence.finding: Score ≥7 associated with 100% amputation rate, useful for decision-making in mangled extremities

clinical_pearls: Time is limb - revascularization within 6 hours improves limb salvage rates
Contralateral saphenous vein is preferred conduit - preserves ipsilateral for future use
Fasciotomy threshold is low after vascular repair - 4-compartment release is standard
Venous repair improves outcomes in combined arteriovenous injuries but is not mandatory
Patients with MESS ≥7 may benefit from primary amputation rather than complex reconstruction
learning_objectives: Distinguish hard from soft signs of extremity vascular injury
Apply ABI for screening in extremity trauma
Determine the appropriate sequence of orthopedic and vascular repair
Select appropriate vascular repair technique based on injury pattern
Calculate MESS score and interpret for amputation decision-making
